paragraphs.title: 1 - View the list of available interpreters
paragraphs.text:
%md

Click on Interpreter binding (Gear icon upper right corner).
This opens a list of interpreters. You can select the interpreters to bound to a notebook.
You can restart an interpreter by clicking Restart. 
Click Cancel.

msg.data:
Click on Interpreter binding (Gear icon upper right corner).
This opens a list of interpreters. You can select the interpreters to bound to a notebook.
You can restart an interpreter by clicking Restart.
Click Cancel.

paragraphs.title: 3 - Run klist and sudo command as user zeppelin, this will fail

msg.data:
klist: No credentials cache found (filename: krb5cc_cldr)

We trust you have received the usual lecture from the local System
Administrator. It usually boils down to these three things:

    #1) Respect the privacy of others.
    #2) Think before you type.
    #3) With great power comes great responsibility.

sudo: no tty present and no askpass program specified

paragraphs.text:
%md

#### Paragraph 3 will fail. The user zeppelin does not have a TGT nor does the user have sudo access. The user zeppelin only provides access to a local shell.

msg.data: Paragraph 3 will fail. The user zeppelin does not have a TGT nor does the user have sudo access. The user zeppelin only provides access to a local shell.

paragraphs.title: 4 - Use su to switch user to run klist to verify the TGT

msg.data:
Password: Ticket cache: KEYRING:persistent:213600001:krb_ccache_Wld2Uat
Default principal: ${CDPADMIN}@EXAMPLE.COM

Valid starting       Expires              Service principal
06/01/2022 10:01:32  06/02/2022 10:01:32  krbtgt/EXAMPLE.COM@EXAMPLE.COM

paragraphs.text:
%md

#### This syntax works. The shell command is executed by an LDAP user, ${CDPADMIN}. The switch user command will change user to a managed user. You must pipe in the passwod. The su - syntax sets the environment for the user. A Kerberos TGT is required to acccess CDP services. You could also use IPA to set a policy granting access through su.

msg.data: This syntax works. The shell command is executed by an LDAP user, ${CDPADMIN}. The switch user command will change user to a managed user. You must pipe in the passwod. The su - syntax sets the environment for the user. A Kerberos TGT is required to acccess CDP services. You could also use IPA to set a policy granting access through su.

paragraphs.title: 5 - Use the kinit to create a TGT
paragraphs.text:
%sh

# Run the kinit command
echo ${PASSWD} | su - ${CDPADMIN} -c 'kdestroy'
echo "Run kinit"
echo ${PASSWD} | su - ${CDPADMIN} -c 'echo ${PASSWD} | kinit ${CDPADMIN}'
echo ${PASSWD} | su - ${CDPADMIN} -c 'klist'

msg.data:

paragraphs.title: 7 - Verify the admin user, ${CDPADMIN}, has superuser privileges
paragraphs.text:
%sh

echo ${PASSWD} | su - ${CDPADMIN} -c "hdfs dfs -mkdir /allan_test"
echo ${PASSWD} | su - ${CDPADMIN} -c "hdfs dfs -ls /"
